Game idea: Civilizations gets tedious because of having to repeat many command/actions, and being subject to many repeating communications. Commands break down to city production and unit instructions. The production queues should be able to be preselected and standardized in advance. Currently cities build one thing at a time. This is silly. Cities should produce and spectrum of things in proportions set by, or influenced by, the player. Movements and unit actions should also be able to be strategized and directed via high level flows and vectors.

For a roleplaying game, really cool storytelling feature: each character has a life story, based on initial distribution of character points amongst attributes. As player gains experience, there are attribute bonuses based on specific actions and patterns. These patch together a new and expanded life story as experience is earned. Since there are distinct types of experience tracked, the content to match those experiences can be created in advance.

In role playing games, limits of strength should limit how much one can carry (consider the popularity of huge unrealistic inventories; different dynamic). This should be something measured as a 1RM or multiple 1RM/max efforts, in a way very true to real fitness, but allowing for monstrous performance (it is fantasy after all). So you start out as weak human/race, and progress to very strong human, into superhuman more or less. Stamina is a direct correlate, and the percentage of effort you expend relative your 1RM/Max determines how much energy it takes in a non-linear way; it is a curve not a line. Strength should also affect need for food; weapon handling recovery from fights and physical efforts.

Imagine a roleplaying game world where player stats reflected quantities we can measure and experience in real life. Focus on nutrition: the food the hero eats, especially in the battlefield, will affect blood sugar, attention & focus, stamina, recovery, etc., and should have long-term effects on learning and mastery of skills. But more significantly, imagine this in a world where players have incentive to create and build, including farming, including rustic permaculture and high-tech bioponics. Players discover that their characters need optimal nutrition for optimal performance, they discover it is easier to make homes and base themselves near other players with a similar attention to excellence and good living. This could be a catalyst of social change.

An intro fitness program should range from 10-50% for elderly, injured, or compromised individuals.  A good general fitness program for a healthy, uninjured person should range from 30-100% of maximum loads and efforts, at various rep and time ranges. Lower that max number to 90%, 80%, 70% or whatever is appropriate to your injuries, needs and condition. A good bodybuilding program should focus on 60-90% loads and efforts.

"Testimonials are the currency of the online knowledge marketplace." A phrase I cooked tonight which I could see being a key tenet of a simple system to help teachers and instructors of all stripes how to build successful online businesses based on truly serving the world through their passion and knowledge. The basic dynamic is simple: give out belabor information free and collect positive testimonials to fuel a website with a product suite based on their expertise.

"What Matters? Crowdsourcing shared values, critical analysis, and practical solutions to unite humanity in common cause to address its challenges." The working title of my book, which will contain chapters and sections on all the major important issues I can see facing humanity today. The book will have prelimary chapters outlining the necessary understandings of logic, history, culture, moral philosophy, etc. Each section or distinct issue will have its own web page, and the book is explicitly geared towards bringing its reading audience online to crowdsource, as the title declares, agreement of common values-based cause, critical analysis of current situation, and possibility-and-solutions-oriented thinking about best ways forward to achieve our common cause ("clean air, water, healthy food, safe communities, healthy happy children, free healthcare and education" etc)

scientific experiments require controlling variables, which implies controlled environments. However, this is impractical for the average person; thus, practicing good science has been impossible to this point for the layperson or average citizen - but not anymore. We can produce cheap, consistent sensors. Experiments, for example the Wifi and plant germination experiment, could be globally distributed. The validity of the data will come from RELATIVE VALUES of variables calculated from the large dataset, rather than ASBOLUTE REPLICATION of variables in a laboratory setting. This is now possible AND practical, where 20, probably even 10 years ago it was not. #openeverything #opendata #openscience

LifeOS feature and use case: "I want to get five important things done every morning before my workout and breakfast. That's my morning routine." Users can create routines, simple scripts that determine how LifeOS presents tasks and reminders. In this case, the user would start the day with LifeOS in focus mode, knowing that five important and not-too-time-consuming tasks are lined up waiting. When these are cleared, the user will be prompted to prepare for their workout (specifics optional). When user cues to continue, the app will go through the entire workout with audio cues, if desired. Same for breakfast; have a recipe read out to you if you want, or just have it linked. Set a list of recipes to circulate or random for that matter. Flexibility is easy with LifeOS.

LifeOS primary focus: make it super-easy and intuitive to create and relate items, categories and contexts. Web browsing is one of our primary use cases: we want to master making sense of your digital footprint. Relate every article and about page, essay and scientific study, email and comment thread, ebooks and podcast, videos viewed and podcasts listened to - all with machine-readable, contextual comments and tags. Simply make a habit of tagging and tracking, and you will accumulate a body of knowledge that will amplify your intelligence over time. Web browsing is your work and livelihood, research and learning, inspiration and entertainment, inspiration and motivation. Your digital journeys can fade away and never amount to anything - if you keep doing what you're doing. Or, you can start to lay down a thread as you go. You do not need to know what will come of this; only that it will make you smarter over time, and yield ideas and opportunities you never would have discovered otherwise. Track it, network it, learn from it, share it.

When LifeOS is truly the main dashboard and command center for your day's activities of work and living, you will be in a position to more effectively plan and track offline activities also. Simply by having your daily routines encoded into LifeOS, you will be able to manage your breaks and end-of-day with iconic reminders and options for what to do, away from the computer. I see an image of Kaya as one option, exercise, the outdoors (get outside for an hour or two!), books, games, social time, etc.

Heterosis: the increased vigor of hybrid offspring. Sometimes taken for granted, though it shouldn't be. Sometimes conflated with the narrow interests of industrial agriculture, though it shouldn't be. The proper general context for heterosis should be in an organic, interconnected, diverse ecosystem. It can be cultivated for human consumption, but certainly we shouldn't regard any "progress" that requires huge industrial inputs to be a real gain over soil-nourishing, ecologically and socially-responsible argiculture and land stewardship.

The childish attitude of "Duh, I already knew that!" carries on for many into adulthood. The rational antidote to this requires two understandings: 1. Understanding that there is a million time more information - particular, detailed facts about the world - that a person could know in a lifetime. The "million" is used qualitatively to mean "many magnitudes". 2. Understanding that there is no "uncommon knowledge", subjectively. Everyone knows a thing or not, to some degree - as things often have complexities, details and nuances that some know more fully than others. The point is that when you know many things, and you also know there is a million times more than you ever can know, an honest and respectful person will not assume on what another person knows. How can I know if you know this thing? And how can you know if I know this thing? Asking and being willing to generously inform each other is good behavior in conversation, and should not provoke a defensive, prideful response about the already-extent of our knowledge.

LifeIQ use case and process note: The TODOist process for adding ideas is pretty slick. Click to app, press 'Q' to 'quick-add task', type it in, [tab] for date, [tab] to project,which provides instant results on character matching, then use arrow key down and [tab] to select, [enter] to add the new task. This is nine (9) actions, including the three entry actions of ideas, date, and project. I think we can do it in less, with more specificity. One key improvement we must make is to present both tag and project hierarchies, as opposed to the flat categories that TODOist present. In tag hierarchies, you can select a high-level tag which will include all descendant tags. In project hierarchies, you can determine which folder/container you want to put the item in.

A small note to bring a bit more useful complexity to LifeIQ, specifically tracking my weed usage: I would like to score wins based on various criteria, for example my existing one-bowl win rule. "Daily Habits" in Habitica imposes penalties for not checking the habit every day. But it also, by the nature of "daily habits", begs to represent a daily routine as well. Routines need some flexibility to adapt to real life; and in the long term, we want them to evolve. The habits serve as "keystones" or foundations to our day and our success; they also serve as anchors around which our daily routine can flex and evolve. When all these disparate functions, currently known as the most successful apps (simple and specialized) are integrated and united, we will realize huge efficiency gains in relating knowledge and resources. Programming insight on recursion: That function objects are things themselves, as well as containing things; and that a function can be recursive precisely because of this property of arrays and objects as being things themselves, as well as containing things. So, function arguments are empty containers, basically meaningless-unless-semantic labels or pointers; as containers, they can contain any item or object, large or small, whole or part; as labels, they can define any item or object, large or small, whole or part. as pointers, they can point to any item or object, large or small, whole or part. The magic of recursion is when we write some function containing operations we want to perform on the parts of a whole (elements of an array or properties of an object); then, from inside of that function, we call the outer function in order to perform those operations on the elememts of our array(s) or the properties of our object(s).

Consider this feature of LifeIQ as it's own framework/module: the keyboard shortcuts MVP. When any modifier key is pressed (ctrl, shift, alt), a fairly subtly modal overlay comes up/in (offcanvas slide in perhaps), showing all of the available keyboard shortcuts; just a thin column with the keys themselves, perhaps with an icon for each. Fuller description is obtained by pressing the key in question, or mousing over it on the overlay. The action will not be performed unless they release the action key prior to the modifer key. "firstimpress.io" for how people receive and perceive our communications. First impression feelings, emotions: people upload monologue or dialogue in text, audio, or video form, and solicit (PPC/monetized or free, interest-driven?) honest feedback from "the crowd" (selectable user group profiles/demographics) about what emotions they perceive in the speaker/text, and what emotions/attitudes they experience as a result. Common emotions will be listed, with sliders for how much/how little of that emotion/attitude is present. Users can enter other, unlisted emotions also - adding them to the crowd-sourced database - and also set their intensity/presence with a slider. This app allows people and organizations to get feedback on what kind of emotions and attitudes are really being communicated/being perceived by the audience/society at large. This can be hugely valuable in the domain of marketing and sales; but it could also be invaluable in the domain of intimate relationships, or in individual personal development (think image consulting for example).

This fundamental oversight has corrupted and misled scientists, increasingly over time, for many decades. It is so obviously wrong, it is an indictment of the level of consciousness of everyone involved in the enterprise of academia.

"Peer-review system" is culturally flawed: then the public are not peers, but implicitly inferior and unqualified to critically analyze science. This is certainly not necessarily true. What is really wanted is a special category of "validated expert review", in addition to the open science public peer review.

Peer-review system as it stands favors studies' initial conclusions over rebuttals, improvements or invalidations. It does this automatically, mechanically by its design - no need for conspiracy. This should be visible when properly analyzed with data science.

Closed science and secret science is anti-social. It's bad for us. We all need to pull together collectively, globally, in good will now with the best knowledge, the best solutions available to all. This is clear and obvious. We need open science. Science both for and by the public, in addition to academia and other institutions.

Stupid people are mucking up the works. To be more diplomatic and true-to-cause: there has been a systematic dumbing-down of people. Intent is a moot point. Results are what we need to deal with, and hopefully systemic causes to address also. We need broad, integrative, creative thinking. Even more importantly, we need independent thinking. The current system is counter to these intelligences. It boxes in, fills up, and turns outward the mind. It cultivates no self-knowledge - a critical requirement for a good scientist. You must know your fallibility by witnessing it in yourself over time; you must have witnessed the fallibility of your perceptions, your rationality, and your righteousness, in order to recognize how much you don't know. In order to ask the right questions, and not make baseless or unquestioned assumptions.

A capability is a human story about what the app can do. It references a real-life example of what a user should be able to accomplish using the app.
Function has multiple meanings. In the mechanical sense, a function is simply something that the app does or can do. In the metaphoric sense, a function is a need which the app fulfills.

A feature, in he vernacular, is something eye-catching or note-worthy. Literally, a feature is anything which could be described. For web development purposes, I'll define a feature as anything a user would identify as a distinct and valuable aspect of the app.

There are values, actions and systems in the world that lead to unnecessary suffering, and reduction of the good things in life. I put all of this stuff together and call it "the old world". 

There are values, actions, and systems that are possible, that are practical, and that are in practice today in the world, that reduce suffering and promote all good things in life. I put all of this stuff together and call it "the new world".

These two world are inseparable and overlapping, but also are fundamentally distinct in character. The old world is deathward: oriented towards and generating death. The new world is lifeward: oriented towards and generating life. The old world is unsustainable with excess; the new world is sustainable with abundance.

In the old world, while there is enough to go around, it doesn't; relatively few have more than they need and waste much, while the majority have less than they need, and live and die on the scraps of the ones who have plenty.

In the new world, everyone cares to ensure that everyone has enough; that the abundance generated in the inseparable web of human accomplishment interwoven with the natural abundance and resource stores of mother nature is enough, and more than enough, if we steward it well. In the new world, the prevailing ethos of human civilization is co-creative progress, and wise stewardship, rather than short-sighted dominance, of the natural world. In the new world, everyone has enough, and their right to live a peaceful, healthy life in dignity is protected by society at large.

From their place in that list, they could be assigned to their final locations, or to intermediary project queues.

I've also been seeking to understand the world; it's overall structure, patterns, and dynamics; the long arc of history: cooperation, culture, power, war, wealth, empire, colonization and genocide.

In the new context of being a bonafide genius (so I believe currently, need to go beyond 144/155/135 online tests) I am exceptional, as I've always felt, for the path I've taken and the experiences I've undergone.

Above 125 IQ (about 1/20, whereas my IQ is likely closer to 1/1000) only 2% "lives in poverty" (should have also ask "have lived"). 10% "out of labor force more than one month out of year" and 2% "unemployed more than one month out of year".

The significant thing about being in this small minority, is that this minority is far more representational of the majority of human beings on the planet, vs. experiencing the upper end of the minority which is the developed world.

So I am perhaps 1/50th of 1/50th of 1/1000th; one in 2.5 million, by that measure; a genius uniquely cognizant of and empathic towards the socio-economic realities and needs of the majority of Earth's people, including our multitudinous flying, swimming, crawling, climbing, burrowing, growing and interconnected non-human family.

It comes from the realization that typical budgets only reflect survival, or if you add additional categories, it is still just a timeless aggregate lump sum. The new view is for the layer above survival; the level of investments in tools and opportunities to increase synergies and get ahead. This new view is for everything about baseline: things that are "extra" in life but will be a net positive, returning benefits over time, often intangibles. This new view is like a GANTT chart, with themes or projects as horizontal periods. Milestones are when the thresholds of investments are reached - set periodic partial payments to reach goals in X time, or project timeframe to reach goal with X periodic payments. So, when the investment is reached, that milestone becomes a tree chart, sprouting (up or down) into branching outcomes. Any outcome that is not immediate will birth its own GANTT line with its own period, and perhaps new milestones and dependencies.

Inspired by a Q&A synopsis of The Filter Bubble, by Eli Parser http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/0143121235?keywords=the%20filter%20bubble&qid=1450568041&ref_=sr_1_1&sr=8-1

Author Q&A with Eli Pariser
 

Q: What is a “Filter Bubble”?

A: We’re used to thinking of the Internet like an enormous library, with services like Google providing a universal map. But that’s no longer really the case. Sites from Google and Facebook to Yahoo News and the New York Times are now increasingly personalized – based on your web history, they filter information to show you the stuff they think you want to see. That can be very different from what everyone else sees – or from what we need to see.

Your filter bubble is this unique, personal universe of information created just for you by this array of personalizing filters. It’s invisible and it’s becoming more and more difficult to escape.

Q: I like the idea that websites might show me information relevant to my interests—it can be overwhelming how much information is available I already only watch TV shows and listen to radio programs that are known to have my same political leaning. What’s so bad about this?

A: It’s true: We’ve always selected information sources that accord with our own views. But one of the creepy things about the filter bubble is that we’re not really doing the selecting. When you turn on Fox News or MSNBC, you have a sense of what their editorial sensibility is: Fox isn’t going to show many stories that portray Obama in a good light, and MSNBC isn’t going to the ones that portray him badly. Personalized filters are a different story: You don’t know who they think you are or on what basis they’re showing you what they’re showing. And as a result, you don’t really have any sense of what’s getting edited out – or, in fact, that things are being edited out at all.

Q: How does money fit into this picture?

A: The rush to build the filter bubble is absolutely driven by commercial interests. It’s becoming clearer and clearer that if you want to have lots of people use your website, you need to provide them with personally relevant information, and if you want to make the most money on ads, you need to provide them with relevant ads. This has triggered a personal information gold rush, in which the major companies – Google, Facebook, Microsoft, Yahoo, and the like – are competing to create the most comprehensive portrait of each of us to drive personalized products. There’s also a whole “behavior market” opening up in which every action you take online – every mouse click, every form entry – can be sold as a commodity.

Q: What is the Internet hiding from me?

A: As Google engineer Jonathan McPhie explained to me, it’s different for every person – and in fact, even Google doesn’t totally know how it plays out on an individual level. At an aggregate level, they can see that people are clicking more. But they can’t predict how each individual’s information environment is altered.

In general, the things that are most likely to get edited out are the things you’re least likely to click on. Sometimes, this can be a real service – if you never read articles about sports, why should a newspaper put a football story on your front page? But apply the same logic to, say, stories about foreign policy, and a problem starts to emerge. Some things, like homelessness or genocide, aren’t highly clickable but are highly important.

Q: Which companies or Websites are personalizing like this?

A: In one form or another, nearly every major website on the Internet is flirting with personalization. But the one that surprises people most is Google. If you and I Google the same thing at the same time, we may get very different results. Google tracks hundreds of “signals” about each of us – what kind of computer we’re on, what we’ve searched for in the past, even how long it takes us to decide what to click on – and uses it to customize our results. When the result is that our favorite pizza parlor shows up first when we Google pizza, it’s useful. But when the result is that we only see the information that is aligned with our religious or social or political beliefs, it’s difficult to maintain perspective.

Q: Are any sites being transparent about their personalization?

A: Some sites do better than others. Amazon, for example, is often quite transparent about the personalization it does: “We’re showing you Brave New World because you bought 1984.” But it’s one thing to personalize products and another to personalize whole information flows, like Google and Facebook are doing. And very few users of those services are even marginally aware that this kind of filtering is at work.

Q: Does this issue of personalization impact my privacy or jeopardize my identity at all?

A: Research psychologists have known for a while that the media you consume shapes your identity. So when the media you consume is also shaped by your identity, you can slip into a weird feedback loop. A lot of people see a simple version of this on Facebook: You idly click on an old classmate, Facebook reads that as a friendship, and pretty soon you’re seeing every one of John or Sue’s posts.

Gone awry, personalization can create compulsive media – media targeted to appeal to your personal psychological weak spots. You can find yourself eating the equivalent of information junk food instead of having a more balanced information diet.

Q: You make it clear that while most Websites’ user agreements say they won’t share our personal information, they also maintain the right to change the rules at any time. Do you foresee sites changing those rules to profit from our online personas?

A: They already have. Facebook, for example, is notorious for its bait-and-switch tactics when it comes to privacy. For a long time, what you “Liked” on Facebook was private, and the site promised to keep it that way. Then, overnight, they made that information public to the world, in order to make it easier for their advertisers to target specific subgroups.

There’s an irony in the fact that while Rolex needs to get Tom Cruise’s permission to put his face on a billboard, it doesn’t need to get my permission to advertise my endorsement to my friends on Facebook. We need laws that give people more rights in their personal data.

Q: Is there any way to avoid this personalization? What if I’m not logged into a site?

A: Even if you’re not logged into Google, for example, an engineer told me there are 57 signals that the site uses to figure out who you are: whether you’re on a Mac or PC or iPad, where you’re located when you’re Googling, etc. And in the near future, it’ll be possible to “fingerprint” unique devices, so that sites can tell which individual computer you’re using. That’s why erasing your browser cookies is at best a partial solution—it only partially limits the information available to personalizers.

What we really need is for the companies that power the filter bubble to take responsibility for the immense power they now have – the power to determine what we see and don’t see, what we know and don’t know. We need them to make sure we continue to have access to public discourse and a view of the common good. A world based solely on things we “Like” is a very incomplete world.

I’m optimistic that they can. It’s worth remembering that newspapers weren’t always informed by a sense of journalistic ethics. They existed for centuries without it. It was only when critics like Walter Lippman began to point out how important they were that the newspapers began to change. And while journalistic ethics aren’t perfect, because of them we have been better informed over the last century. We need algorithmic ethics to guide us through the next.

Q: What are the business leaders at Google and Facebook and Yahoo saying about their responsibilities?

A: To be honest, they’re frustratingly coy. They tend to frame the trend in the passive tense: Google’s Eric Schmidt recently said “It will be very hard for people to watch or consume something that has not in some sense been tailored for them,” rather than “Google is making it very hard…” Mark Zuckerberg perfectly summed up the tension in personalization when he said “A squirrel dying in your front yard may be more relevant to your interests right now than people dying in Africa.” But he refuses to engage with what that means at a societal level – especially for the people in Africa.

Q: Your background is as a political organizer for the liberal Website MoveOn.org. How does that experience inform your book?

A: I’ve always believed the Internet could connect us all together and help create a better, more democratic world. That’s what excited me about MoveOn – here we were, connecting people directly with each other and with political leaders to create change.

But that more democratic society has yet to emerge, and I think it’s partly because while the Internet is very good at helping groups of people with like interests band together (like MoveOn), it’s not so hot at introducing people to different people and ideas. Democracy requires discourse and personalization is making that more and more elusive.

And that worries me, because we really need the Internet to live up to that connective promise. We need it to help us solve global problems like climate change, terrorism, or natural resource management which by their nature require massive coordination, and great wisdom and ingenuity. These problems can’t be solved by a person or two – they require whole societies to participate. And that just won’t happen if we’re all isolated in a web of one.

This may sound like a bombastic claim, but I think it's easy to see how LifeIQ can help people "learn and practice how to live life better." Consider the timeless metaphor of life as a journey, each of us choosing our own path. Let's make a modern upgrade to the image, and have us all piloting our own personal aircraft (where's my aircar already?). Well, the reality is that most people are operating blind and on autopilot; the sensors have biases, and the autopilot is bugy, with flawed or defective programming. The guidance system is conflicted, lacks a clear direction or practical wayfinding function, and to top it all off - most of us are utterly neglecting the care and maintenance of our vessels as we go through this life. 

Now, let's bring in a process of reflection and clarification of goals and purpose; let's found this on a new foundation of relationship with reality, as we begin daily tracking of everything that matters most to us. Add in effective planning, habits engineering, gamification, and the tools to build integrity through effectiveness. We begin to practice life mastery; that perennial path of those who pursue excellence persistently, because principle or passion drives them to do so.

Can a pursuit of success or mastery in life be supported or augmented by a tool that unifies your values, goals, knowledge and actions? Yes, it can.

Consider my usual conception of a concept map or network graph of data: nodes and connections, relationships. Well, in the real world, people are nodes of the highest interest. Consider the set of people in a particular field, say medicine, psychotherapy for example; each doctor is a node in that set. Each node accrues value over its lifetime, but how much of that knowledge and experience has been augmented by data-driven feedback? By video-recorded peer feedback? How much has been shared, and how effectively, to move the field forward? Mostly, these "nodes" are siloed, isolated for the most part, exchanging and passing on a lesser part of their potential. We need systems to spring up across all disciplines and fields; consider again this therapy, we need group of peers, students and researchers to form privacy-bound study groups with therapists and clients. They need to circulate amongst therapists, and provide systemic feedback amongst all the practicing doctors in the cohort. I always wanted a regular co-teaching/mentor-shadow model as a snowboard instructor in Whistler. This would be like that, but systematized, conceptually standardized but customized to be domain-appropriate.

More from the same source which applies to LifeIQ (hidden state are those annoying actions that produce no visible result, like regular "habits" in habitica.com):

Code manipulates data. To understand code, a learner must see the data, and see the effect of code on the data.

1. The environment must show the data. If a line of code computes a thing, that thing should be immediately visible.

2. The environment must show comparisons. If a program computes many things, all of those things should be shown in context. This is nothing more than data visualization.

3. The system must have no hidden state. State should either be eliminated, or represented as explicit objects on the screen. Every action must have a visible effect.

He's spending a good deal of time discussing syntax in languages and how they evolved from early days. He's now (~12:00) discussing how syntax variations (the if/fi of Algol 68) can affect the programmer's ability to scan/identify relevant blocks in the code visually (as curly brace closures are all generic). This raises the interesting point, as related strongly to the recent reads on "A Universal Tree Editor", "Learnable Programming" and "Model-Driven Development": why stick to ASCII-based visual clues to the structure of our code, and to machine-abstracted syntax for the function and meaning of it? Why not work with our human faculties: use visual information for program structure, and (more-)natural human language for the meaning, and natural-language/iconic/symbolic language for function.
Indeed, closing with "Don't forget your semi-colons!" is indicative of where a software developer/programmer's attention is mis-applied, misappropriated by the syntax and development environment.

Quoting:
Rapid Logging
Note-taking and traditional journaling take time; the more complex the entry, the more effort is expended. The more effort expended, the more of a chore it becomes, the more likely you’ll underutilize or abandon your journal. Rapid Logging is the solution. Rapid Logging is the language in which the Bullet Journal is written. It consists of four components: topics, page numbers, short sentences, and bullets.

For lifeIQ: components:

Topics = tags, categories, URLs

Page numbers = date-time stamp as unique ID; instant character-matching search and filter by tag, text or data; multiple list, map and graph views of all or any part of the entire network of knowledge.

Short sentences = write as much as you want; content as unique ID. Machine parsing of natural-language data entry, inline.

Bullets = Item classes or item properties.  An item class is a unique set of properties which applies consistently to members of that class. Properties combine into classes, and classes combine into superclasses. Properties include creation date-time, any tags, links or URLs, content, attachments, styling, state, reminders(events), possibly version history, and custom data properties ("Rate the intensity of your workout 1-10", "Assign/estimate the time required for this task/project: ____ min/hrs/days/weeks" etc)

Also inspired a UI feature: in AgileZen, task state is signified by which column it is located in - the general principle of kanban. In LifeIQ, perhaps I'll use the idea of an archive column: drag any item to the right edge of the screen and watch it drop into the well. However, I would like by default to maintain some visual feedback of work completed. I think a thin right column with simple colored dots/circles representing tasks completed, per day, with color gradation representing the timeline.

Note they do have two additional task states which are unrelated to column placement: each task/story has a "ready" state which can be activated when it is complete. This allows collaborators to mark their work as complete without having to dictate workflow to teammates (developers can decide which story to work on next from those queued as "Ready"). Also, there is a "blocked" state, which includes reason for block, and which applies attention-getting styling.

Note they have a good feature where they have a "process" view which allows users to CRUD/re-order the cards(steps) which make up the process. Any sequential workflow could be modeled. Once the user has created their process, the "board" view is where the work happens.

From https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Inventor%27s_paradox
" or, in other words, to solve what one desires to solve, one may have to solve more than that in order to get a properly working flow of information.[2]

When solving a problem, the natural inclination typically is to remove as much excessive variability and produce limitations on the subject at hand. Doing this can create unforeseen and intrinsically awkward parameters.[3] The goal is to find elegant and relatively simple solutions to broader problems, allowing for the ability to focus on the specific portion that was originally of concern.[4]

There lies the inventor's paradox, that it is often significantly easier to find a general solution than a more specific one, since the general solution may naturally have a simpler algorithm and cleaner design, and typically can take less time to solve in comparison with a particular problem.[3]"

LifeOS feature and use case: "I want to get five important things done every morning before my workout and breakfast. That's my morning routine." Users can create routines, simple scripts that determine how LifeOS presents tasks and reminders. In this case, the user would start the day with LifeOS in focus mode, knowing that five important and not-too-time-consuming tasks are lined up waiting. When these are cleared, the user will be prompted to prepare for their workout (specifics optional). When user cues to continue, the app will go through the entire workout with audio cues, if desired. Same for breakfast; have a recipe read out to you if you want, or just have it linked. Set a list of recipes to circulate or random for that matter. Flexibility is easy with LifeOS.
